In a partially ordered set with a greatest element, the greatest element is the unique element that is less than or equal to itself.

type: âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [inst : PartialOrder Î±] [inst_1 : OrderTop Î±] {a : Î±}, âŠ¤ â‰¤ a â†” a = âŠ¤
name: top_le_iff
docString: In a partially ordered set with a greatest element, the greatest element is the unique element that is less than or equal to itself.

This theorem, `Nat.le_findGreatest`, asserts that for any natural number `m` and a decidable predicate `P` (a predicate for which we can definitively say whether it is true or false), if `m` is less than or equal to `n` and `P(m)` holds true, then `m` is less than or equal to the greatest natural number `i` less than or equal to `n` for which `P(i)` holds. In other words, if `m` satisfies the predicate `P` and is within the bounds of `n`, it cannot be larger than the greatest such number that fulfills these conditions.

type: âˆ€ {m : â„•} {P : â„• â†’ Prop} [inst : DecidablePred P] {n : â„•}, m â‰¤ n â†’ P m â†’ m â‰¤ Nat.findGreatest P n
name: Nat.le_findGreatest
docString: This theorem, `Nat.le_findGreatest`, asserts that for any natural number `m` and a decidable predicate `P` (a predicate for which we can definitively say whether it is true or false), if `m` is less than or equal to `n` and `P(m)` holds true, then `m` is less than or equal to the greatest natural number `i` less than or equal to `n` for which `P(i)` holds. In other words, if `m` satisfies the predicate `P` and is within the bounds of `n`, it cannot be larger than the greatest such number that fulfills these conditions.

In any nontrivial partially ordered set with a least (bottom) and greatest (top) element, the least and greatest elements are distinct.

type: âˆ€ {Î± : Type u} [inst : PartialOrder Î±] [inst_1 : BoundedOrder Î±] [inst_2 : Nontrivial Î±], âŠ¥ â‰  âŠ¤
name: bot_ne_top
docString: In any nontrivial partially ordered set with a least (bottom) and greatest (top) element, the least and greatest elements are distinct.

The theorem `Nat.findGreatest_le` states that for any natural number `n` and any decidable predicate `P` on natural numbers, the greatest natural number `i` less than or equal to `n` for which `P(i)` holds is always less than or equal to `n`. If there is no such `i` (i.e., if `P(i)` does not hold for any `i` less than or equal to `n`), then by definition, `Nat.findGreatest P n` is `0`, which is also less than or equal to `n`. This theorem is a property of the `Nat.findGreatest` function in Lean 4, which finds the greatest natural number that satisfies a given predicate.

type: âˆ€ {P : â„• â†’ Prop} [inst : DecidablePred P] (n : â„•), Nat.findGreatest P n â‰¤ n
name: Nat.findGreatest_le
docString: The theorem `Nat.findGreatest_le` states that for any natural number `n` and any decidable predicate `P` on natural numbers, the greatest natural number `i` less than or equal to `n` for which `P(i)` holds is always less than or equal to `n`. If there is no such `i` (i.e., if `P(i)` does not hold for any `i` less than or equal to `n`), then by definition, `Nat.findGreatest P n` is `0`, which is also less than or equal to `n`. This theorem is a property of the `Nat.findGreatest` function in Lean 4, which finds the greatest natural number that satisfies a given predicate.
